Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: P2C2--Tree-Ring Reconstructions of Western North Pacific Climate Dynamics
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research, generally, seeks to provide a more integrative understanding of the spatiotemporal variability of trans-North Pacific climate through the use of new and existing data sets of tree rings.

Specifically, the researchers seek to answer the following scientific questions: 1) How has the North Pacific atmosphere-ocean circulation varied over the past several centuries to millennium during such events as the Medieval Climate Anomaly and the Little Ice Age; 2) Can different paleoreconstructions of Pacific Decadal Variability (PDV) be reconciled? 3) Is the PDV during the recent era (e.g. 1976-77 Pacific warming, regime shift) unique relative to past centuries? 4) Do robust and preferred decadal to multidecadal oscillatory modes of PDV exist? 5) Is the PDV basin-wide with robust linkages between the tropics and higher northern latitudes on both sides of the North Pacific? and 6) How have internal and external forcings impacted past North Pacific climate on multiple timescales?

The potential broader impacts include supporting an early investigator and strong and substantive scientific collaboration with Russian colleagues including foreign exchange of students between the U.S. and Russia.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project’s principal goal was to enhance our knowledge of  past climate variability of the western North Pacific sector, including areas of the Russian Far East, eastern Siberia and Japan. Because meteorological records for many of the remote areas of the western North Pacific region are only  a few decades long in some cases, we have extended these climatic data using so-called proxy or paleoclimatic  records from  tree rings. The tree-ring width series that we have produced are based on wood samples collected from living and dead wood material (of spruce, pine, oak, birch, larch and fir and other tree species) which spans back centuries or more, and which are precisely dated at annual resolution. These data were used to generate long, sensitive records of past climate variability,  including past temperatures and indices of atmosphere-ocean circulation – e.g. the Pacific Decadal Oscillation (PDO), the dominant mode of extratropical climate variability in the sea surface temperatures of the North Pacific ocean. This report describes our efforts over the past several years to improve our coverage and knowledge of decadal to longer-term climate variability of the western North Pacific region and the greater North Pacific sector over the past centuries to millennium.
